Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Highly Porous Metal Tibia in Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: 397 patients (age 67.8 ± 8.7 years; 54% female) were randomised into three groups

Intervention.evidence: highly porous metal tibia with a traditional modular cemented tibia

Objective.evidence: aimed to compare the effectiveness of a highly porous metal tibia with a traditional modular cemented tibia

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was survivorship at 5 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Stratified randomisation was performed based on surgeon, patient’s age, sex, and body mass index.

Number_Analysed.evidence: Four patients were lost to follow-up before 2 years.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Survivorship at 5 years was similar across groups (96.8% [1]; 97.6% [2]; 96.7% [3]; p = 0.59).

Harms.evidence: complication rates were comparable between groups.

Trial_Registration.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.

Funding.evidence: Trial registration and funding details were not provided.
